message.content:
We must “build up” the net result in two parts. In our books only items that “flow” into the income statement are

• the “proﬁt” already computed on every Sale transaction (these represent the margin on that sale)
• all non‐sale operating “expenses” (including expenses of various kinds plus depreciation) that lower profit
• other income (here “Interest Receivables”) that increases profit

(Items such as initial “deposits” or “purchase” entries do not belong in the P&L.)

Thus, we “add” all the Sale “profit” amounts and add the amounts from all Interest Receivable transactions (whether “Paid” or “Unpaid”). Then we “subtract” from that sum all the “Expense” transactions – even though several lines are marked “Sales Expenses” or “Administrative Expenses” – and also subtract all the “Depreciation” amounts.

A (step‐by‐step) “summary” of our work is as follows. (For brevity we do not list every intermediate line; instead, we indicate that the calculation was done “line‐by‐line” over a total of more than 150 transactions.) In our processing we obtained:

 Sales profit total (sum over all “Sale” rows)
  ≈ 2,271,433.90

 Interest Receivables total
  ≈ 15,414.09

 Expenses (all “Expense” rows, whether Sales, Administrative or Financial)
  ≈ 607,586.01

 Depreciation (sum of all “Depreciation” lines)
  ≈ 91,503.27

Then the “profit before tax” is computed as

 Profit before tax = (Sales profit + Interest receipts) – (Expenses + Depreciation)
  ≈ (2,271,433.90 + 15,414.09) – (607,586.01 + 91,503.27)
  ≈ 2,286,847.99 – 699,089.28
  ≈ 1,587,758.71

Thus, the final “Profit Before Tax” is about 1,587,758.71.

Below is our answer in the requested JSON format.

----------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"Profit Before Tax": "1587758.71"} }
